thread.title: The week in numbers to July 10
thread.title_full: The week in numbers to July 10

title: The week in numbers to July 10
text:
Fri, Jul 10, 2015, 12:14 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 3 hrs 46 mins The week in numbers to July 10 AAP – 16 minutes ago 
The big and small numbers that grabbed attention - or should have - in the business world over the past week. 
Monday: 
$30bn - That's how much was wiped off the Australian stock market's value in just the opening minutes of trade, after Greece rejected its creditors' proposed austerity measures. The market recovered later in the day, though still shed more than $18 billion in value. 
Tuesday: 
$600b - The iron ore industry is expected to contribute more than $600 billion to the Australian economy over the next decade, despite falling prices for the steel making commodity. 
Wednesday: 
6.72 pct - China's benchmark Shanghai stock index plunged by nearly seven per cent in early trade as additional government moves failed to shore up the tumbling market. Its recent falls have so far wiped $US3.2 trillion from the market. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index ended the day 5.9 per cent weaker. 
Thursday: 
120,000 - The latest jobs figures show about 120,000 jobs have been created so far this year, at an average of 20,000 a month, bringing the June unemployment rate to six per cent. 
Friday: 
9.9 pct - Chinese iron ore prices climbed 9.9 per cent to $US48.99 a tonne on Thursday night, regaining virtually all the ground lost on Wednesday when prices dived 10 per cent to $US44.10 a tonne. Talk about a roller coaster ride. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook PM backs Joyce despite anger over mine AAP 
Prime Minister Tony Abbott has again excused Barnaby Joyce's outburst over a Chinese coal mine in his NSW electorate, …
